thread.title: Labour is 'fighting fit' and gearing up for a snap general election
thread.title_full: Labour is 'fighting fit' and gearing up for a snap general election

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Labour is 'fighting fit' and gearing up for a snap general election
text:
News Labour is 'fighting fit' and gearing up for a snap general election The Labour party is prepared for a fight whenever it comes, says North East senior MP Ian Lavery Share Ian Lavery MP for Wansbeck speaks at the 2016 Labour Conference in Liverpool Share Get   Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Labour is “fighting fit” and ready to take on the Tories in a snap general election, a North East Shadow Cabinet member says. 
Ian Lavery , MP for Wansbeck and a member of Jeremy Corbyn’s front bench team, issued the warning to Prime Minister Theresa May. 
He spoke after Labour’s ruling body, the party’s National Executive Committee, met to discuss election strategy. 
Jon Trickett, a senior figure in the shadow cabinet, said staff were on an election footing and laid out the party’s plans to move to bigger offices. 
There is speculation that Prime Minister Theresa May could call an election if she struggles to win support from her own MPs for the Government’s Brexit strategy. 
Mr Lavery said: “The situation is that volatile that there is every possibility a snap election cold be caled. 
“Things are changing almost daily, and the Prime Minister could decide her best hope is to go to the polls. 
“As far as the Labour Party is concerned, we believe there is a prospect of a snap election probably in early spring next year. 
“We have geared up. We have got people in position. We have got the campaign up and ready for any eventuality.” Read More 
He added: “We’re ready to fight what promises to be an important battle. 
“We have got the finances in place and we are on the front foot.” 
Labour is reported to have commissioned the polling company BMG and branding agency Krow Communications, which worked with Team GB athletes, ready for a snap poll. 
And the party is to hire more campaign staff and move into bigger offices thanks to funding from the summer leadership election, when thousands of people paid £25 to become registered members, allowing them to vote for party leader Jeremy Corbyn or challenger Owen Smith. Like us on Facebook
